column4: What is the simpliest, easiest way to get a static IPv6 address on an Ubuntu 8.04 server from behind a NAT device?
your NATing device should not matter at all as long as it can route IPv6
however, you still need your ISP to allocate you an IPv6 address (or a block of addresses :))
I want to be able to ssh into my server using IPv6, so I'll need an address with global scope.
you need to ask your ISP to give you that.
If I could get a /64 from my ISP, that would be wonderful, but that's not going to happen.
The only solution I know of is a tunnel broker. Right now I'm using teredo, but it's miserable.
then I don't think there is much you can do... besides using tunnel brokers.
contact your ISP and ask them what it would take to get a block.
So the question becomes: which tunnel broker uses the client-side software that's easiest to set up on Ubuntu 8.04?
I think they just don't do that.
search the repos for ipv6 stuff? maybe you'll find a hint
<accent type="indian">I'm sorry sir, but Qwest does not offer IPv6 service.</accent>
Incidentally, where do you live that you think you might be able to get IPv6 service from an ISP?
